The lymphatic system is a network of vessels throughout the body, whose primary function is to remove excess tissue fluid squeezed out from capillaries. Oxygenated blood passes through these vessels---arteries--narrower arterioles and finally even narrower capillaries. However, even with many narrow capillaries, not every cell in the body can obtain the metabolic products it needs directly from the capillaries. Therefore, the final journey of these compounds is via a liquid solution which bathes the tissues-this is tissue fluid. Blood pressure increases as blood is squeezed into narrower and narrower vessels. Blood pressure in capillaries is so high that blood plasma is forced out under ultrafiltration from the capillaries-This plasma, along with dissolved molecules eg glucose, oxygen, amino acids etc. forms the tissue fluid. Cells absorb glucose and oxygen and release CO2 and waste products to the tissue fluid. This fluid must be returned to the circulatory system (eg back to the blood) to allow tissues to keep getting the substances they need. Most tissue fluid returns to the capillaries (as blood in capillary now has lower water potential than tissue fluid as blood plasma squeezed out+lots of undiluted proteins remain in blood-also loss of blood plasma has reduced blood pressure to lower than hydrostatic pressure of tissue fluid-so there is a pressure gradient too). However, not all tissue fluid can be returned via the capillaries. The rest returns via lymphatic system-Initially resembles capillaries but then merges into larger vessels and combines with vena cava just before entry to the heart to return to blood+remove waste products. Tissue fluid is moved along lymph by hydrostatic pressure gradient of tissue fluid (high at tissues, lower at vena cava end-so fluid moves down pressure gradient) and the contraction of muscles (the same as how blood moves through veins). Also, a system of valves ensure fluid only flows in 1 direction (again like veins). I hope this helps. It's basically just another network of vessels that return excess blood plasma to the blood after being squeezed out of capillaries :) Sorry for rambling!

Hermaphrodites, while born with both sex organs, usually have only one being functional rather than both which is how they identify which gender to "make" the baby into. So for example, if one had both female and male reproductive parts, it could have the exterior of the female but no working inside sections. However, if it had functional male organs, then it would be classified as male and vice versa. Doctors would then "close" the female sections and the baby would grow up a boy. In the opposite situation, they'd remove the exterior, non-functioning male parts and it would grow up a girl.

Not all animals want to reproduce... just look at the panda :P  But seriously, nature cares not for the refusal of a single individual to reproduce, but rather looks at the big picture of the population as a whole.

For humans, and quite possibly a number of other more neurologically complex organisms, the picture has more dimensions. Even excluding all that, the issue has more dimensions, for example: for each social species of ant and bee the vast majority of offspring will not develop a drive to reproduce before their life cycle ends. If it has any bearing on the thoughts you mean to bring up, ants and bees still represent vastly successful strategies (never mind the fact bees are getting to be in danger of fading away. That's another consequence of factors relating to human artifices.)  For human dimensions though I might suggest "The Selfish Gene", a book by Richard Dawkins. I believe that's where the word "meme" was stolen from to be repurposed as a more specific term for viral internet bullshit.  On the other hand, with respect, I don't understand how desire for reproduction in all animals can be interpreted as the main point of the videos. Hank has several times said that biology is about sex and not dieing, but those are main themes underpinning biology in general, not the main point of the videos, and they are main themes only in regards to biology taken from a certain perspective. Even then it's an intentional simplification.

It's true that a YY chromosome wouldn't survive, but there's a bit of a catch, and addresses the "what about YY?" question.  A YY chromosome can be inherited, but a YY embryo would fail to thrive and be miscarried. This is due to the fact that a large number of genes required for life to even be possible exist solely on the X chromosome.  It is possible for XYY  and XXY (Klinefelter syndrome) chromosomes to occur and not only survive to birth, but thrive and lead generally normal lives.
